04:49 on the 8th UTC) in the [[Gulf of Tehuantepec]] off the southern coast of [[Mexico]], near state of [[Chiapas]], approximately {{convert|87|km|mi}} south of [[Pijijiapan]], with a [[Mercalli intensity scale|Mercalli intensity]] of IX (''Violent'').{{cite news |date=8 September 2017 |title=Earthquake of magnitude 8.1 strikes off Mexico's Pacific coast |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-41197831 |work=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}}{{cite web |title=M 8.1 – 87 km SW of Pijijiapan, Mexico |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/pt17251000 |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |accessdate=7 September 2017}} The magnitude was estimated to be {{m|w|8.2|link=y}}.[https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us2000ahv0#executive USGS]. The earthquake caused some buildings in [[Mexico City]] to tremble, prompting people to evacuate. It also generated a [[tsunami]] with waves of {{convert|1.75|m}} above tide level; and tsunami alerts were issued for surrounding areas.{{cite web |date=8 September 2017 |title=Tsunami Message Number 5 (0653 UTC Fri Sep 8 2017) |url=http://tsunami.gov/events/PHEB/2017/09/08/17251000/5/WEPA40/WEPA40.txt |publisher=[[National Weather Service]] (United States) |accessdate=8 September 2017}} Mexico's president called it the strongest earthquake recorded in the country, in a century. It was also the second strongest recorded in the country's history, behind the [[1787 New Spain earthquake|magnitude 8.6 earthquake in 1787]],{{cite news|last1=Richard Hartley|first1=Parkinson|title=Most powerful earthquake in 230 years hits Mexico sparking tsunami|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/09/08/tsunami-warning-as-magnitude-8-earthquake-rocks-mexico-6911929/|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=Metro|date=8 September 2017}} and the most intense recorded globally in 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/browse/m7-world.php?year=2017|title=World – M7+ in 2017|website=earthquake.usgs.gov|access-date=8 September 2017}} == Tectonic setting == The [[Gulf of Tehuantepec]] lies above the [[convergent boundary]] where the [[Cocos Plate]] is being [[Subduction|subducted]] below the [[North American Plate]] at a rate of 6.4 cm/yr (2.5 in/yr).{{cite journal|last=Singh|first=S.K.|author2=M. The incident prompted a review of the system.{{cite news |date=6 September 2017 |title=Se activa, por error, alerta sísmica en CDMX; descartan sismo |trans-title=Seismic alert in CDMX is activated by mistake; disregard earthquake |language=Spanish |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/metropoli/cdmx/se-activa-por-error-alerta-sismica-en-cdmx-descartan-sismo |work=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]] |accessdate=7 September 2017}} == Earthquake == [[File:People in Mexico City Downtown after 2017 Chiapas earthquake.jpg|thumb|People outside a hotel in Mexico City a few minutes after the earthquake.]] According to the [[National Seismological Service]] (SSN) of Mexico, the [[epicenter]] was located in the Gulf of Tehuantepec, about {{convert|137|km}} southeast of [[Tonalá, Chiapas]]. The [[United States Geological Survey]] (USGS) reported that the epicenter was about {{convert|87|km}} southwest of [[Pijijiapan]], Chiapas. The SSN reported a measurement of [[Moment magnitude scale|M]] 8.2,{{cite web |date=8 September 2017 |title=Reporte de Sismo: Sismo del día 07 de Septiembre de 2017, Chiapas (M 8.2) |trans-title=Earthquake Report: Earthquake of 7 September 2017, Chiapas (M 8.2) |language=Spanish |url=http://www.ssn.unam.mx/sismicidad/reportes-especiales/2017/SSNMX_rep_esp_20170907_Chiapas_M84.pdf |publisher=[[National Seismological Service]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} while the USGS also reported a M 8.2 earthquake after correcting an earlier estimate of M 8.0. The earthquake was a result of [[Fault (geology)#Dip-slip faults|normal faulting]] within the Cocos Plate with a displacement of up to {{convert|10|m|ft|0}}.{{cite news |last=Osborne |first=Hannah |date=8 September 2017 |title=Biggest earthquake to hit Mexico in over a century moved fault by 32 feet |url=http://www.newsweek.com/mexico-earthquake-biggest-century-seismologist-aftershocks-661919 |work=[[Newsweek]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} The earthquake is the most powerful to be measured in Mexico since the [[1985 Mexico City earthquake]],{{cite news |last1=Linthicum |first1=Kate |last2=Lin II |first2=Rong-Gong |date=8 September 2017 |title=Mexican authorities report an 8.4 earthquake off southern coast, raising tsunami fears |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-me-earthquake-mexico-8-20170907-story.html |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Schladebeck |first=Jessica |date=8 September 2017 |title=Mexico hit by 8.4 earthquake, tsunami warnings issued |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/mexico-hit-8-0-earthquake-tsunamis-article-1.3479356 |work=[[New York Daily News]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} and is comparable to the [[1932 Jalisco earthquakes]].{{cite news |last=Lafuente |first=Javier |date=8 September 2017 |title=Un fuerte terremoto sacude el sur de México |trans-title=A strong earthquake shakes southern Mexico |language=Spanish |url=https://elpais.com/internacional/2017/09/08/actualidad/1504847379_494928.html |work=[[El País]] |location=Madrid |accessdate=8 September 2017}} Mexican President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] called the earthquake the "largest in at least a century" and claimed that it was felt by 50 million people.{{cite news |last=Partlow |first=Joshua |date=8 September 2017 |title=At least 58 killed in massive earthquake off Mexico coast |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/massive-earthquake-strikes-off-the-coast-of-mexico-setting-off-tsunami-warnings/2017/09/08/c8114f3a-945b-11e7-aace-04b862b2b3f3_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=8 September 2017}} Geophysicists at the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] speculated that the earthquake relieved stored pressure in the "Tehuantepec gap", making future earthquakes in the region less likely.{{cite journal |last=Wade |first=Lizzie |date=15 September 2017 |title=Unusual Mexico earthquake may have relieved stress in seismic gap |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/09/unusual-mexico-earthquake-may-have-relieved-stress-seismic-gap |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science Magazine]] |volume=357 |issue=6356 |page=1084 |doi=10.1126/science.357.6356.1084 |issn=1095-9203 |oclc= 1644869 |accessdate=19 September 2017}} === Tsunami === A [[tsunami]] with waves of {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and higher was generated by the earthquake and was recorded at [[Salina Cruz]];{{cite news |date=8 September 2017 |title=Mexico earthquake: mass evacuations after strongest tremor in a century |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/08/mexico-earthquake-warning-tsunami |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} A tsunami wave of {{convert|1.75|m|ft|abbr=on}} was reported in Chiapas.{{cite web|author1=Pacific Tsunami Warning Center|authorlink1=Pacific Tsunami Warning Center|title=Tsunami Message Number 17|url=http://ptwc.weather.gov/ptwc/text.php?id=pacific.TSUPAC.2017.09.08.1827|publisher=[[National Weather Service]]|accessdate=8 September 2017|location=Ewa Beach, Hawaii|date=8 September 2017}} The [[Pacific Tsunami Warning Center]] issued a [[Tsunami warning system|warning]] for the entire Pacific coast of [[Central America]], also extending south to [[Ecuador]].{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/08/mexico-earthquake-magnitude-8-tremor-rattles-buildings-capital/|title=Mexico hit by 'strongest earthquake in a century' as magnitude 8.2 tremor triggers tsunami waves – latest news|work=The Telegraph|last1=Graham|first1=Chris|last2=Johnson|first2=Jamie|last3=Strange|first3=Hannah|last4=Badcock|first4=James|date=8 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://english.manoramaonline.com/news/world/2017/09/08/earthquake-hits-mexico-tsunami-warning.html|title=At least six die in huge Mexico quake, small tsunami triggered – Video|publisher=|accessdate=8 September 2017}} === Aftershocks === In the hour following the earthquake, at least 12 [[aftershock]]s were recorded by the USGS.{{cite news |last1=Malkin |first1=Elisabeth |last2=Ramzy |first2=Austin |date=8 September 2017 |title=Strong Earthquake Hits Off Mexico’s Coast |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/08/world/americas/mexico-earthquake.html?_r=0 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} As of 00:30 September 14 ([[UTC|UTC Time]]), the [[National Seismological Service]] (SSN) has recorded at least 1,806 aftershocks, of up to a magnitude of 6.1. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- ! # ! image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 | header = Damage to [[Juchitán de Zaragoza]] City Hall | image1 = Juchitán.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = City Hall in November 2006 | image2 = Enrique Peña Nieto y Alejandro Murat Hinojosa visitan una zona afectada por el sismo del 7 de septiembre2.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = City Hall on 8 September 2017 }} Within Chiapas, an estimated 1.5 million people were affected by the earthquake, with 41,000 homes damaged.{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/b7d17e0dbbff48a381a58b64353abe23/Death-toll-rises-to-60-in-powerful-Mexico-earthquake|title=Death toll rises to 60 in powerful Mexico earthquake|date=9 September 2017|accessdate=9 September 2017|publisher=[[Associated Press]]}}{{cite news |date=10 September 2017 |title=Thousands of homes wrecked by huge Mexican quake, death toll at 90 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-quake-mexico/thousands-of-homes-wrecked-by-huge-mexican-quake-death-toll-at-90-idUSKCN1BL06A |work=Reuters |accessdate=10 September 2017}} [[Jose Calzada]], [[Secretariat of Agriculture, Livestock, Rural Development, Fisheries and Food (Mexico)|Minister of Agriculture]], reported that at least 98 people had died in the earthquake, including 78 in [[Oaxaca]], 16 in Chiapas and 4 in [[Tabasco]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1066148.shtml|title=Death toll from Mexico earthquake climbs to 98 – Global Times|last=Times|first=Global|website=www.globaltimes.cn|access-date=16 September 2017}} The [[Secretariat of the Interior (Mexico)|Secretariat of the Interior]] declared a state of emergency for 122 municipalities in Chiapas,{{cite news |last=Mandujano |first=Isaín |date=8 September 2017 |title=La Segob declara "emergencia extraordinaria" en 122 municipios de Chiapas por sismo |trans-title=Secretariat of the Interior declares "extraordinary emergency" in 122 Chiapas municipalities after earthquake |language=Spanish |url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/502358/la-segob-declara-emergencia-extraordinaria-en-122-municipios-chiapas-sismo |work=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} and the [[Mexican Army]] was deployed to aid in disaster relief.{{cite news |last=Garcia |first=Dennis A. |date=8 September 2017 |title=Sedena aplica Plan DN-III-E en Chiapas y Oaxaca |trans-title=Sedena applies DN-III-E plan in Chiapas and Oaxaca |language=Spanish |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/seguridad/sedena-aplica-plan-plan-dn-iii-e-en-chiapas-y-oaxaca |work=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} Schools were closed on 8 September in 11 states for safety inspections.{{cite news |last1=Sherman |first1=Cristopher |last2=Castillo |first2=Eduardo |date=8 September 2017 |title='The house moved like chewing gum': Dozens killed in Mexico earthquake as country braces for hurricane |url=http://nationalpost.com/news/world/newsalert-earthquake-measuring-8-0-strikes-off-southern-mexico |agency=Associated Press |work=[[The National Post]] |location=Toronto |accessdate=8 September 2017}} Damage in [[Veracruz]] was reported, meanwhile the state is expecting the arrival of [[Hurricane Katia (2017)|Hurricane Katia]] on 9 September. [[Hurricane Max (2017)|Hurricane Max]] made landfall in [[Guerrero]] state on 14 September, near the earthquake-stricken region.{{cite news |date=15 September 2017 |title=Hurricane Max lashes earthquake-hit area of southwest Mexico |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/hurricane-max-lashes-earthquake-hit-area-of-southwest-mexico-9218106 |work=Channel NewsAsia |accessdate=15 September 2017}} Buildings in [[Juchitán de Zaragoza]], [[Oaxaca]], closest to the epicenter, were "reduced to rubble" according to reports from the town's mayor.{{cite news |last=Cortes |first=Jose |date=8 September 2017 |title=At least 58 die in Mexico's strongest quake in 85 years |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-quake-mexico/at-least-58-die-in-mexicos-strongest-quake-in-85-years-idUSKCN1BJ0FW |work=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=8 September 2017}} The earthquake also caused buildings to shake and sway in [[Mexico City]], while also knocking out electricity for 1.8 million people. There were reports of glass shattered at [[Mexico City International Airport]].{{cite news|last1=Malkin|first1=Elisabeth|last2=Ramzy|first2=Austin|title=Mexico Earthquake, at 8.1 Magnitude, Is Felt for Hundreds of Miles|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/08/world/americas/mexico-earthquake.html?mcubz=3|accessdate=8 September 2017|work=The New York Times|date=8 September 2017}} An under construction highway bridge near Mexico City's [[New International Airport for Mexico City|new international airport]] collapsed due to the shaking.{{cite news |last=Navarro |first=Andrea |date=13 September 2017 |title=In Mexico City Mud, Pena Nieto’s $13 Billion Airport Project Bogs Down |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-13/in-mexico-city-mud-pena-nieto-s-13-billion-project-bogs-down |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |accessdate=14 September 2017}} The epicenter was near [[Guatemala–Mexico border|Mexico's border with Guatemala]], where the quake was felt in [[Guatemala City]], and infrastructure damage was reported by [[Coordinadora Nacional para la Reducción de Desastres|CONRED]] in the nation's south-west. President [[Jimmy Morales]] stated that one Guatemalan may have been killed.{{cite news |last1=Linthicum |first1=Kate |last2=Sanchez |first2=Cecilia |date=8 September 2017 |title=From toppled buildings to at least 32 deaths, Mexico's most powerful quake in years prompts chaos |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-mexico-earthquake-20170908-story.html |work=The Los Angeles Times |accessdate=8 September 2017}} File:Enrique Peña Nieto y Alejandro Murat Hinojosa visitan una zona afectada por el sismo del 7 de septiembre1.jpg|President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] inspecting damage to a home in Juchitán, Oaxaca File:Centro de acopio - Terremoto de Chiapas de 2017.jpg|Collection Center for the victims of the earthquake, Mexico City City Hall. == Response == On 11 September, Mexico recalled its aid to the United States, offered in the aftermath of [[Hurricane Harvey]], to focus on earthquake recovery.{{cite news |last=Agren |first=David |date=11 September 2017 |title=Mexico withdraws Harvey aid offer as it focuses on earthquake recovery |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/11/mexico-earthquake-aid-withdraw-hurricane-harvey |work=The Guardian |accessdate=11 September 2017}} United States President [[Donald Trump]] called Mexican President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] on 14 September, a week after the earthquake, to express his condolences. Trump's delayed call, which he blamed on cellular signal problems, was criticized by some media outlets in both countries.{{cite news |last=Partlow |first=Joshua |date=14 September 2017 |title=Was it just the cell signal? Mexicans wonder why Trump took so long to offer his earthquake condolences. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/09/14/was-it-just-the-cell-signal-mexicans-wonder-why-trump-took-so-long-to-offer-his-earthquake-condolences/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=19 September 2017}} == See also == {{GeoGroupTemplate}} {{Commons category|2017 Chiapas earthquake}} * [[2017 Central Mexico earthquake]] * [[List of earthquakes in 2017]] * [[List of earthquakes in Mexico]] {{Portal bar|2010s|Earthquakes|Mexico}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://temblor.net/earthquake-insights/m6-1-mexican-aftershock-strongly-promoted-by-m8-1-chiapas-mainshock-5317/ M=6.1 Mexican aftershock strongly promoted by M=8.1 Chiapas mainshock] – [[Temblor, Inc.]] *{{EQ-isc-link|611600536}} {{Earthquakes in 2017}} {{Earthquakes in Mexico}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chiapas earthquake, 2017}} [[Category:2017 earthquakes]] [[Category:2017 in Guatemala]] [[Category:Earthquakes in Guatemala]] [[Category:Earthquakes in Mexico|2017]] [[Category:History of Chiapas|2017 earthquake]] [[Category:History of Oaxaca|2017 earthquake]] [[Category:September 2017 events in Mexico]] [[Category:Megathrust earthquakes in Mexico]]
